turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Do you find it somewhere in our cases?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --The precise formulation comes from the suggestion in Calero-Toledo.
The--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: From a dictum in... and that is enough to adopt it?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --No, it's not enough, and we don't believe that that's all that supports the all reasonable steps standard.
Both... the history supports the broad principle, in fact, that limits the Government's ability to punish essentially blameless people by taking away their property.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: What history does that, when we've certainly done it with respect to vessels.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: That's right, and even as long ago, however, as a case like Peisch v. Ware, Chief Justice Marshall wrote for the Court in 1808 that a property should not be forfeited when the owner of the property lacks the means to prevent the forfeiture.
Now, that suggestion of powerlessness to control the events leading to the forfeiture is different from the later formulation in Calero-Toledo, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Was he speaking of constitutional law--

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --He was not speaking of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: --or of equitable power to declare the forfeiture?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --He was speaking in terms of longstanding principles.
It's not--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And in Goldsmith we upheld the forfeiture of a conditional vendor's interest in an automobile because the buyer who's driving it around used it for drugs.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --That's right, and we see two lines of cases, really, one of which includes Goldsmith, Grant, Van Oster, and Calero-Toledo itself, which recognizes that a property owner cannot avoid the forfeiture of property that's been used illegally merely by showing that she lacked knowledge or even reason to know of the illegal use.
By the same token, there is another different line of cases, of which Calero-Toledo is also a part, that recognizes limitations on the Government's ability to punish people.
Now, that actually brings--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: They do that in dictum, whereas the other cases do it in holding, don't they?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --That's correct.
This Court--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: It seems a rather significant distinction.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --It is a significant distinction.

The one exception I would note to that, but it's not a forfeiture case, is the one we cite in our brief, Southwestern Telephone & Telegraph Company v. Danaher, which involved the Court... in which the Court set aside a $6,300 civil penalty against a phone company on the grounds that the phone company had acted reasonably and there was no wrongdoing that justified--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Seamons, one thing I don't understand is how you put together your test with your end result, because it seems to me that in many, many, perhaps most marital situations, a person in Tina Bennis' situation could do everything within her power to do, but the law gives the co-owner the right to use the car whenever and however he wants, so I don't see how the all reasonable steps would work out to the disfavor of someone in Tina Bennis' situation.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --It may be that--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ginsburg
turn.text: She has no power over him.
She could say everything she wants and it's not going to do any good.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --Our view of the result, I suppose, is in part based on presumptions about how the State law operates in terms of the degree of control that a joint owner can exercise over another owner.
Certainly, it would not be reasonable to expect a co-owner to do anything that she didn't have a right to do under the State law.
On the other hand, every citizen can take certain measures to prevent illegal activity that comes... that they learn about, including calling the police, and so it's simply not clear--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ginsburg
turn.text: How is a Tina Bennis supposed to make sure that her spouse doesn't use a car this way?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --It's very difficult to know in the absence of knowing more about how much knowledge or reason to suspect that use she had, which is unclear to us on this record.
In our view, all that she showed in the trial court was that she lacked actual knowledge of the illegal use, but she did not show that she lacked a reason to suspect that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Would it have been a different case, in your view, if she had gotten on the witness stand and said, this all came as a very shocking surprise to me, I had no idea this was going on?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: That would be the difference.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: Yes, but I would emphasize in answering the question that it has a lot to do with the nature of the offense involved here, which is I think another complication.

I mean, it is reasonable to expect that a husband who frequents prostitutes will hide that fact from his wife and be able to do that successfully, but that may not necessarily be true if a different offense is involved, such as ongoing drug trafficking, and--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Kennedy
turn.text: In this case, your office has taken the position we should affirm the judgment of the Michigan court--

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Kennedy
turn.text: --despite this very troubling question about the wife's knowledge of her husband's activities and her ability to do anything about it.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: That's right.
We believe that the record, in fact, is unclear on the question of whether she could have taken any reasonable steps to prevent--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice Souter
turn.text: Let's see where we would go with it.
Take the easy case in which she says, yes, I knew he was doing this.
There wasn't anything I could do about it.
He owns as much of the car as I do.
What was she supposed to do?
In that... I take it in your view, her interest would be subject to forfeiture on those facts, based on that testimony, is that correct?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --Our view of the proper disposition of this case is based--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice Souter
turn.text: Well, no, I'm talking about my case, the one in which she takes the stand and says, I knew he was doing it, but I didn't have any right to stop him from using the car, and let's further assume that as a co-owner in Michigan, she didn't.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --No, I'm sorry, that's not our position.

It is our position that even if an owner has knowledge of ongoing unlawful activity with regard to her own property, it still remains... can make out the defense by showing that she took all reasonable steps to prevent it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice Souter
turn.text: Well, is right to control the touchstone for determining what is reasonable?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: It certainly is one of the foundations.
Anything that one doesn't have a right to do--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice Souter
turn.text: Okay.

You're not taking the position, say, in the case that I put... the wife says I knew, and so on... you're not taking the position that she was supposed to call the police and say, you better watch out for such-and-such a car, because my husband is engaging in illegal acts in it.
You're not taking that position, are you, or are you?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --No, not exactly.
Our position is... it is not our position that if you know, you lose.
On the other hand--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice Souter
turn.text: Well, you're not taking the position that she affirmatively had to call the police.
Now, you're saying that control is very significant.
What else is?
What's in the middle between these two extremes?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --Well, I'd say there are two elements.
Besides control, the other element is the extent to which the person knows or has reason to know that her property is being used illegally.
I mean, it is true that in--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice Souter
turn.text: But that gets us back to the control issue.
She... on my hypothesis, she knows beyond a peradventure of a doubt, but she can't control the car, and you... I think you're saying she is not required to call the police.
What else should we look at to determine whether she has taken every reasonable step to preserve her innocence for constitutional purposes?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --On that point, I... we would expect property owners to notify the police if they know that the property is being--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Kennedy
turn.text: So it's the position of the Solicitor General's Office that wives should call the police--
--Yes.
--when their husbands are using prostitutes?

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --Not in every case, but it is certainly one--
[Laughter]
It is certainly one--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Kennedy
turn.text: Don't let the laughter of clerks who have never even argued a case in a municipal court deter you from your answer.

turn.speaker: richard_h_seamon
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Seamon
turn.text: --Thank you.

One, what's reasonable depends on the circumstances of every case, and it's easier to understand my answer, I think, in the fact situation that comes up all too frequently, I'm sorry to say, in Federal cases where the husband is dealing drugs, using the car or the house to deal the drugs, and the wife has knowledge of that, and in those cases the Federal Government does indeed take the position that the wife is obligated, in order to protect her property interests, in order to be able to assert an innocent owner defense, to notify the police.
Now, there are steps short of that that a wife may very well decide to take.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Seamon.
The case is submitted.
